I am trying to use the MIT soot mechanism, which involves non-integer
stoic=
hiometric coefficients.

The cti file was created successfully, but once I =
run my calculation, I
get the following error message:

___________________=
_____________________________________________________
_____________
***** E=
rror parsing input file *****
zero or negative stoichiometric coefficient: =
0.866667 BIN4 + 0.133333
BIN5 + 0 H2 + H

...

Procedure: checkRxnElementBa=
lance
Error:   The following reaction is unbalanced:
        C6H5 + A1C2HJ2=
 =3D> 0.583333 BIN1 + 1.5 H2

        Element    Reactants    Products
    =
    C           14           14
        H           10           10
_______=
_________________________________________________________________
_________=
____

Is Cantera able to handle these non-integer coefficients ?


Thank yo=
u in advance,

Laurent







--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin=
 <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:

Stoichiometric coefficients must be integers.  For=
 the reaction you 
cite, specify it as

2 CH4 + 3 O2 =3D> 2 CO + 4 H2O

The=
n cut the pre-exponential term in the rate expression by two, since 
as wri=
tten here this reaction consumes two CH4, instead of 1, as 
originally writ=
ten.  Since you are specifying the reaction orders for 
the reactants, the =
stoichiometric coefficients will not be used in 
computing the reaction rat=
e of progress, only in converting from rate 
of progress to species product=
ion rates.

Cantera requires integer stoichiometric coefficients since this=
 allows 
using some faster numerical algorithms and there is no loss of 
ge=
nerality, since every balanced reaction can be written with integer 
stoich=
iometric coefficients.  In particular, species production rates 
are comput=
ed from the reaction rates of progress using integer addition 
operations, =
instead of floating-point multiplies. Also, except when a 
reaction order i=
s explicitly specified (as in this reaction), rates of 
progress are comput=
ed using integer multiply operations, instead of 
floating-point exponentia=
tion.   All of this turns out to make a big 
difference in the performance =
using large mechanisms, and is one main 
reason that flame calculations, fo=
r example, are often faster with 
Cantera than with "other well-known softw=
are packages."  (There are 
other reasons, too.)

Dave
